Kutcher tells Council about water situation

  • Comments

Posted: Friday, October 27, 2017 12:00 am

Kutcher tells Council about water situation By JOHN WRIGHT • jwright@murrayledger.com murrayledger.com | 0 comments

MURRAY — City of Murray Director of Public Works & Utilities Tom Kutcher updated Mayor Jack Rose and the members of the city council Thursday about the ongoing water situation in Murray during Thursday’s regularly-scheduled meeting at City Hall. 

Two construction incidents Wednesday night led to an estimated 27,000 customers in the city and throughout Calloway County being placed under a boil water order. Kutcher said the five operators of the city’s drinking water facility on L.P. Miller Drive, along with all 12 workers with a contractor handling the job, were working around the clock to get the situation under control Thursday.

<script type="text/javascript">




	/*
	 * Handle visit duration
	 */

	var mixpanel_visit_start = new Date();
	var mixpanel_content_viewed_args;
	var mixpanel_window_hidden_timer = null;

	function mixpanel_track_content_viewed() {
	
		if(typeof mixpanel !== "undefined"){
			var mixpanel_visit_end = new Date();
			var duration = mixpanel_visit_end.getTime() - mixpanel_visit_start.getTime();
			duration = parseInt(duration / 1000);
			mixpanel_visit_start = new Date(); //reset the visit start time
			
			if(duration>0){
				mixpanel_content_viewed_args.$duration= Math.min(duration, 3600);
			}else{
				mixpanel_content_viewed_args.$duration="";
			}
			
			mixpanel.track("content view ended", mixpanel_content_viewed_args);
			
		}
		return null;
		
	};
	window.onbeforeunload = function() {
		mixpanel_track_content_viewed();
		//avoid next call of mixpanel_track_content_viewed()
		mixpanel_track_content_viewed = function () {}
		//Add a "sleep" timeout to be more sure that the mixpanel call is sent
		timer = new Date();
		while(new Date() - timer < 300) {};
	}


	/* get property for when the page is hidden */
	function getHiddenProp() {
		var prefixes = ['webkit', 'moz', 'ms', 'o'];
		// if 'hidden' is natively supported just return it
		if ('hidden' in document) return 'hidden';

		// otherwise loop over all the known prefixes until we find one
		for (var i = 0; i < prefixes.length; i++) {
			if ((prefixes[i] + 'Hidden') in document)
				return prefixes[i] + 'Hidden';
		}
		// otherwise it's not supported
		return null;
	}

	// listen for page visibility changes
	var visProp = getHiddenProp();
	if (visProp) {
		var evtname = visProp.replace(/[H|h]idden/, '') + 'visibilitychange';
		document.addEventListener(evtname, visChange);
	}
	/* returns true if the page is not visible */
	function isHidden() {
		var prop = getHiddenProp();
		if (!prop) return false;
		return document[prop];
	}

	function visChange() {
		if (isHidden()) {
			handleHidden();
		} else {
			handleVisible();
		}
	}

	function handleHidden() {
		clearTimeout(mixpanel_window_hidden_timer);
		mixpanel_window_hidden_timer = setTimeout("mixpanel_track_content_viewed()",500);
	}

	function handleVisible() {
		if(mixpanel_window_hidden_timer){
			clearTimeout(mixpanel_window_hidden_timer);
		}else{
		mixpanel_visit_start = new Date(); //reset the visit start time
	}
	}

	
	
	/*
	 * Set gtx_session_id  and "first time user" super property
	 */

	var gtx_session_id = "";
	var gtx_is_first_time_user = null;
	if (typeof(Storage) !== "undefined") {
		var gtx_session_length = 1800;
		var now = parseInt(new Date().getTime() / 1000);
		var gtx_session_last_activity = localStorage.getItem("gtx_session_last_activity");
		var gtx_first_user_session_id = localStorage.getItem("gtx_first_user_session_id");
		
		gtx_session_id = localStorage.getItem("gtx_session_id");
		if(!gtx_session_id || !gtx_session_last_activity || now - gtx_session_last_activity > gtx_session_length ){
			gtx_session_id = Date.now() +"-" + Math.random().toString(36).substring(7,17);
			localStorage.setItem("gtx_session_id", gtx_session_id);
			if(!gtx_first_user_session_id){
				gtx_first_user_session_id = gtx_session_id;
				localStorage.setItem("gtx_first_user_session_id", gtx_session_id);
			}
		}
		if(gtx_first_user_session_id == gtx_session_id){
			gtx_is_first_time_user = true;
		}else{
			gtx_is_first_time_user = false;
		}
		
		localStorage.setItem("gtx_session_last_activity", now);

	}

	/*
	 * Track all links
	 */
	jQuery( document ).ready(function( $ ) {
		$('body').on('click', 'a[href]', function( e ) {
			
			var $element = $(this);
			var element = $element.get(0);
			if( !element || !element.href ) return;
			
			//check if it's an anchor link
			if( element.href.indexOf('#') == 0 || element.href.indexOf(window.location.href+'#') == 0 ) return;
			
			if($element.data("ssbp-site")){
				//It's a simplesharebuttons click
				if($element.data("ssbp-site").toLowerCase() != 'ellipsis'){
					var link_data = mixpanel_get_simplesharebutton_link_data( element );
					mixpanel.track("content shared", link_data);
				}
			}else{
				var link_data = mixpanel_get_link_data( element );
				mixpanel.track("link clicked", link_data);
			}
	 		
		});
	});
	
	function mixpanel_get_link_data( element ){
		
		$element = jQuery( element );
		var link_data ={
						'link type': 'other',
						'source title': "Under boil order, Murray awaits water test results",
						'source url': document.location.href,
						'source post id': 77222,
						'desitination url': element.href,
						'destination domain': element.hostname,
						'source page type': 'single'	 
						
						/* Other attributes set either below or with data-mp-*: */
						
						//'destination title': '',		
						//'destination post ID': '',		
						//'link type': '', //content list, related articles, external, menu, other
						//'content list title': '',		
						//'content list index': '',

					}
		
		var hostname = element.hostname || $element.hostname || ""
		if(hostname && document.location.hostname != hostname){
			link_data["link type"] = "external";
		}
		
		// get all $element's data-mp-* attributes and add to the array
		var el_atts = $element.get(0).attributes;
		for ( var k in el_atts){
			if(isNaN(k)) continue;
			if( typeof el_atts[k] != 'object' || el_atts[k] == null || typeof el_atts[k].nodeName != 'string' ) continue;
			attr = el_atts[k].nodeName
			if(attr.substring(0,8) == 'data-mp-'){
				var attr_name = attr.substring(8).replace(/\-/g,' ');
				link_data[attr_name] = el_atts[k].value;
			}
		}
		
		//detect if it's a related posts with thumbnail link - yuzo style 1 and 2
		if($element.parent().parent().hasClass("relatedthumb")){
			link_data["link type"] = "related articles";
			link_data["destination title"] = $element.find(".yuzo__text--title").text().trim();
			link_data["content list index"] = $element.parent().parent().index() +1;
			
			var dest_id_match = $element.parent().parent().attr("class").match("relatedpost-([0-9]+)");
			if(dest_id_match && dest_id_match[1]){
				link_data["destination post ID"] = dest_id_match[1];
			}
		}
		
		//detect if it's a related posts link - yuzo style 3 and 4
		else if($element.hasClass("yuzo__text--title")){
			link_data["link type"] = "related articles";
			link_data["destination title"] = $element.text().trim();
			link_data["content list index"] = $element.parent().index() +1;
		}
		
		//detect if it's a menu link
		else if($element.parent().hasClass("menu-item")){
			link_data["link type"] = "menu";
			link_data["menu link index"] = $element.parent().index() +1;
			link_data["menu id"] = $element.parent().parent().attr('id');
			
			//destination post ID set by destination post ID and title set in data attributes
		}

		//detect if it's breaking news link
		else if($element.hasClass("gtx-breaking-news-message")){
			if( $element.parent().parent().parent().data('type') == 'list' ){
				link_data["link type"] = "breaking news list";
			}else{
				link_data["link type"] = "breaking news banner";
			}
			link_data["breaking news index"] = $element.parent().parent().index() +1;
			link_data["breaking news text"] = $element.text().trim();
			
			//destination post ID set by destination post ID and title set in data attributes
		}
		
		//detect link position in page
			if($element.parents("header").length > 0){
				link_data["position in page"] = "header";
			}else if($element.parents("footer").length > 0){
				link_data["position in page"] = "footer";
			}else if($element.parents("main").length > 0){
				link_data["position in page"] = "main";
			}else if($element.parents(".sidebar").length > 0){
				link_data["position in page"] = "sidebar";
			}
			
		return link_data;
	
	}


	function mixpanel_get_simplesharebutton_link_data( element ){
		
		$element = jQuery( element );
		var link_data ={
						'title': "Under boil order, Murray awaits water test results",
						'url': document.location.href,
						'post ID': 77222,
						'share type': $element.data("ssbp-site").toLowerCase(),						
						//'completed': '',	
					}

		return link_data;
	
	}



	/*
	 * Set super properties
	 */
	 
    try {
        var is_touch		= (("ontouchstart" in window) || window.DocumentTouch && typeof DocumentTouch != "undefined" && document instanceof DocumentTouch || false);
    }
    catch(err) {
        var is_touch = "Unknown"
    }

    mixpanel.register({
        "platform": "web",
        "touch device": is_touch,
        "publication id": 17077,
    	"publication name": "wpsdlocal6",
        "session id": gtx_session_id,
        "first time user": gtx_is_first_time_user
    });	


		
</script>

<main class="col-sm-12 col-xs-12 col-md-8" id="main" itemprop="mainContentOfPage" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Blog" role="main"> <article class="cf post-77222 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-news category-local-news category-home-top-story tag-boil-water-order tag-calloway-county tag-cause tag-kentucky tag-murray tag-school-closed single cf" data-post-id="77222" id="post-77222" role="article"><div class="basic-content-wrap cf"> <div class="basic-content-wrap cf">
<h1 class="entry-title">Under boil order, Murray awaits water test results</h1>
<div class="entry-meta-wrapper">
<div class="entry-meta entry-date">
<time class="updated entry-time" itemprop="datePublished">October 26, 2017</time>
</div>
<div class="entry-meta entry-author">
<span class="by"></span>
<a href="http://www.wpsdlocal6.com/author/wpsd-staff/">
						WPSD Staff					</a>
</div>
</div>
<div class="loop-wrapper articles"></div><p><img alt="" class="alignright wp-image-77225" height="225" sizes="(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px" src="http://www.wpsdlocal6.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/water-faucet.jpg" srcset="http://www.wpsdlocal6.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/water-faucet.jpg 640w, http://www.wpsdlocal6.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/water-faucet-300x169.jpg 300w" width="400"/>MURRAY, KY – The city of Murray has released more information about a boil water order that <a href="http://www.wpsdlocal6.com/2017/10/26/boil-water-order-customers-murray-water-system/" rel="noopener" target="_blank">went into effect Thursday morning</a> and has led the <a href="http://www.wpsdlocal6.com/2017/10/26/school-canceled-due-boil-water-order/" rel="noopener" target="_blank">Murray and Calloway County public school districts</a> to announce Friday closures.</p>
<p>The Murray Water System detected increased turbidity — meaning cloudiness caused by particles — in the water Thursday morning, the city says. The water company issued a boil order as a precaution until the utility gets the results of sample tests from throughout the water system.</p>
<p>The city says Murray Water System expects it will have the test results sometime Friday evening or Saturday morning. The utility suspects the turbidity increase was caused by vibration near a clear well and a penetration of a 30-inch water main. Both of those incidents happened Wednesday afternoon while contractors were performing construction work near the Murray Water System water plant.</p>
<p>Murray Water System customers are advised to boil all drinking water taken from the public water systems, as well as any water used to make ice cubes, wash food, brush teeth, and any other water you would consume in any other way.</p>
<p>The utility says water should be brought to a full, rolling boil for at least 5 minutes. You can boil water ahead of time and store it in a closed container either at room temperature or in your refrigerator to use later.</p>
<p>The Calloway County Health Department has released information on precautions you should take during a boil water order. To read that fact sheet, <a href="http://www.wpsdlocal6.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/Calloway-County-boil-order-safety-fact-sheet.pdf" rel="noopener" target="_blank">click here</a>.</p>
<p>Below, you can read the full news release sent about the order from the Murray mayor’s office.</p>
<iframe class="pdfjs-viewer" height="600" src="http://www.wpsdlocal6.com/wp-content/plugins/pdf-viewer/stable/web/viewer.html?file=http://www.wpsdlocal6.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/murray-boil-order-update.pdf" width="100%"></iframe>

									var keyA = ( a.modified ? a.modified : 0 );
									var keyB = ( b.modified ? b.modified : 0 );

									if(keyA < keyB) return 1;
									return 0;
								});


                                // Create an associative object with all channels
                                for( i=0; i<entries.length; i++){
                                    entries[i].channelsAssociative = {};
                                    for( j=0; j<entries[i].channels.length; j++){
                                        var attr_key = entries[i].channels[j].type;
                                        var attr_val = entries[i].channels[j];
                                        entries[i].channelsAssociative[attr_key] = attr_val;

                                    }
                                }


								$(".gtx-breaking-news").each(function(){
									var limit = parseInt($( this ).attr('data-limit')|| 1) ;
									var breaking_news_type = $( this ).attr('data-type');
									if(!breaking_news_type) breaking_news_type = 'single';
									var html = link = message = image = "";
                                    var platform = 'web';

                                    var j=0;
									for( i=0; i<entries.length && j < limit; i++){
										try{
											var entry = entries[i];
											var expiration = 0;
											var link = message = image = '';
											var channelSettings = {};
											var article = entry.articleData || {};
												
											// Default to breaking news type for backwards compatibility
											if( !entry.className ) {
												entry.className = 'breaking-news';
											}

                                            if(breaking_news_type == 'single'){
                                                channelSettings = entry.channelsAssociative.web_banner;
                                            }else if(breaking_news_type == 'list'){
                                                channelSettings = entry.channelsAssociative.web_list;
                                            }else if(breaking_news_type == 'app_single'){
                                                channelSettings = entry.channelsAssociative.app_banner;
                                                platform = 'app';
                                            }else if(breaking_news_type == 'app_list'){
                                                channelSettings = entry.channelsAssociative.app_list;
                                                platform = 'app';
                                            }else{
											    continue;
                                            }

                                            if(channelSettings.excluded) continue;

                                            message = channelSettings.message || entry.defaultMessage || entry.title || '';
                                            expiration = channelSettings.expires || 0;
                                            image = article.feed_gtx_image || '';
                                            if(platform=='app'){
                                                link = article.feed_link || '';
                                            }else{
                                                link = channelSettings.link || article.feed_link || '';
                                            }

                                  			var expiration_formatted = new Date(parseInt(expiration));
											expiration_formatted = expiration_formatted.toISOString();

                                            if(!expiration || expiration == 0 ){
												//not active
												continue;
											}else if(expiration > 0 && expiration < new Date().getTime()){
												//expired
                                                continue;
											}else{
												//Is not expired
											}

											html = html + '\
											<div class="gtx-breaking-news-article gtx-breaking-news-article-id-' + entry.articleId + ' gtx-breaking-news-article-i-'+i+' gtx-breaking-news-img-left">\
												<div class="thumb-wrap">\
													'+ (link?'<a href="'+ link +'" class="gtx-breaking-news-img-wrapper">':'<span class="gtx-breaking-news-img-wrapper">')+' \
														'+(image?'<img src="'+ image +'" class="gtx-breaking-news-img " >':'')+'\
													'+ (link?'</a>':'</span>')+' \
												</div> \
												<div class="entry-content-wrap">\
													'+ (link?'<a href="'+ link +'" class="gtx-breaking-news-message">':'<span class="gtx-breaking-news-message">')+' \
														'+ message +' \
													'+ (link?'</a>':'</span>')+' \
												</div> \
											</div>';
										
											j++;
										} catch(err) {
											console.log(err)
										}
									}
									$(this).addClass( entry.className );
									$(this).html(html);
								
								});
							}
						});
					});

Puerto Ricans at Risk of Waterborne Disease Outbreak in Wake of Hurricane Maria

"It's like a perfect storm for leptospirosis, people are going to get sick and suffer," said one nurse who'd been on the island

    NEWSLETTERS

    Receive the latest national-international updates in your inbox

    Privacy policy | More Newsletters

    Puerto Rico's continued struggles after Hurricane Maria include the rise of waterborne illnesses, which health professionals fear may grow to become an epidemic, NBC News reported.

    Two of the most recent deaths came from leptospirosis, a bacterial disease that's usually spread through contaminated water, a health official told The Associated Pres, and 74 suspected cases of infection are being investigated.

    • GOP Shoves Tax Overhaul Ahead; Shutdown Still a Threat

    The rare disease, treated with antibiotics, is transmitted through the urine of infected animals, but humans are usually infected by coming in contact with infected water. One in four people on the island still didn't have access to running water by Wednesday.

    "It's like a perfect storm for leptospirosis, people are going to get sick and suffer," said nurse Llamara Padro-Milano, who came back from a relief trip to the island last week. She said nurses were encountering cases of pink eye as well.

    Get More at NBC News
    Published at 6:17 AM CDT on Oct 26, 2017

            Published 12:02 a.m. ET Oct. 26, 2017
        </span></div></section><section class="storytopbar-bucket piano-module story-piano-module" id="module-position-Qcz8BbqT3Eo"></section><section class="storytopbar-bucket bounce-exchange-module story-bounce-exchange-module" id="module-position-Qcz8Bbre11Y"></section><section class="storytopbar-bucket google-survey-module story-google-survey-module" id="module-position-Qcz8Bbrhbxs"></section><!-- p402_premium class is utilized by Google Consumer Surveys --><div class="asset-double-wide double-wide p402_premium" itemprop="articleBody" role="main"><div class="story-asset story-metadata-asset" id="module-position-Qcz8BdjwhD8"><div class="article-metadata-wrap"><section class="storymetadata-bucket expandable-photo-module story-expandable-photo-module" id="module-position-Qcz8Bdg7ETU"><aside class="single-photo expandable-collapsed" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject"><div class="image-wrap"><img alt="2017 335104988-TDNBrd_DETROIT_03-07-2017_TDNXX_1_A003~~2017~03~06~IMG_file_-.jpg" class="expand-img-horiz" data-mycapture-sm-src="https://www.gannett-cdn.com/-mm-/ae8c18203a33be29888b2941e900df4ccd37225c/r=500x352/local/-/media/2017/10/25/DetroitNews/B99590999Z.1_20171025190054_000_G8F1N8DG5.1-0.jpg" data-mycapture-src="https://www.gannett-cdn.com/media/2017/10/25/DetroitNews/B99590999Z.1_20171025190054_000_G8F1N8DG5.1-0.jpg" itemprop="url" src="https://www.gannett-cdn.com/-mm-/e0de737dca5f5443b5aa100179b6c6ec47ea9948/c=138-0-4455-3238&r=x404&c=534x401/local/-/media/2017/10/25/DetroitNews/B99590999Z.1_20171025190054_000_G8F1N8DG5.1-0.jpg"/><span class="toggle"></span><meta content="2017 335104988-TDNBrd_DETROIT_03-07-2017_TDNXX_1_A003~~2017~03~06~IMG_file_-.jpg" itemprop="name"/></div><p class="image-credit-wrap"><span class="js-caption-wrapper"><span class="cutline js-caption">Flint Mayor Karen Weaver and Gov. Rick Snyder at a 2016 news conference on the city's water crisis.</span><meta content="" itemprop="copyrightHolder"/><span class="credit">(Photo: Dale G. Young / Detroit News file)</span></span></p></aside></section></div></div><div class="story-asset inline-share-tools-asset" id="module-position-Qcz8BdjFSek"><div class="inline-share-tools asset-inline-share-tools asset-inline-share-tools-top"><span class="inline-share-btn inline-share-btn-facebook" data-share-method="facebook" data-uotrack="InlineShareFacebookBtn"><span class="inline-share-count inline-share-count-facebook"></span><span class="inline-share-btn-label inline-share-btn-label-facebook">CONNECT</span></span><a class="inline-share-btn inline-share-btn-twitter" data-popup="" data-popup-height="450" data-popup-width="550" data-share-method="twitter" data-uotrack="InlineShareTwitterLink" href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=http%3A//detne.ws/2iBLe5n&text=Howes%3A%20In%20Flint%20water%20war%2C%20city%20only%20has%20one%20choice&via=detroitnews" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"><span class="inline-share-count inline-share-count-twitter"></span><span class="inline-share-btn-label inline-share-btn-label-twitter">TWEET</span></a><a class="inline-share-btn inline-share-btn-linkedin" data-popup="" data-popup-height="455" data-popup-width="600" data-share-method="linkedin" data-uotrack="UtilityBarFlyoutLinkedInLink" href="http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?url=http%3A//detne.ws/2iBLe5n&mini=true" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"><span class="inline-share-count inline-share-count-linkedin">
            
                4
            
        </span><span class="inline-share-btn-label inline-share-btn-label-linkedin">LINKEDIN</span></a><span class="inline-share-btn inline-share-btn-comments" data-share-method="comments" data-uotrack="InlineShareCommentsBtn"><span class="inline-share-count inline-share-count-comments">
                
                    2
                
            </span><span class="inline-share-btn-label inline-share-btn-label-comments">COMMENT</span></span><span class="inline-share-btn inline-share-btn-email" data-share-method="email" data-uotrack="InlineShareEmailBtn"><span class="inline-share-count inline-share-count-email"></span><span class="inline-share-btn-label inline-share-btn-label-email">EMAIL</span></span><span class="inline-share-btn inline-share-btn-more" data-share-method="facebook" data-uotrack="InlineShareMoreBtn"><span class="inline-share-count inline-share-count-more"></span><span class="inline-share-btn-label inline-share-btn-label-more">MORE</span></span></div></div><p class="speakable-p-1 p-text"><span class="-newsgate-macro-cci-drop-initial-"></span>A nearly week-long boil-water order in Oakland County may not instill confidence in Flint City Council members being pushed to green-light the cash-strapped city’s deal with the Great Lakes Water Authority.</p><p class="speakable-p-2 p-text">They’d be wise to consider the alternatives. None of them is particularly good for a place steeped in the politics of water, bureaucratic incompetence at all levels of government and the high costs of making bad decisions.</p><p class="p-text">In a filing in federal court, Mayor Karen Weaver is accusing City Council of stalling its decision to approve a contract with GLWA. It would tie the city’s water supply to the metro Detroit authority for 30 years — and offset $444,000 in monthly bond payments by Flint to the nearby Karegnondi Water Authority.</p><p class="p-text">Council’s refusal to act effectively has “put the public’s health at risk and created an inevitable timetable for possible receivership and/or bankruptcy of the city of Flint,” the filing says. And it accuses council of “dereliction of their fiduciary duties.”</p><div class="partner-placement partner-spike"></div><p class="p-text">Probably so — but for two mutually exclusive forces: the city’s shaky financial condition and the understandable skepticism of council members and the residents they represent. When state officials largely to blame for a lead-contamination crisis in the city’s water sue to enforce their preferred deal with GLWA, it’s natural for council members to balk.</p><p class="p-text">Wouldn’t you? Consider the sordid history of the Flint water crisis, the long paper trail documenting it, the implication of local, state and federal officials, the congressional hearings, and, yes, the racial implications of the whole mess.</p><p class="p-text">This has “mistrust” written all over it. Still, slow-walking a water deal that is probably the city’s only meaningful alternative amounts to spending money Flint can ill-afford to spend — $1.7 million and counting since July, the mayor told The Detroit News this week.</p><div class="partner-outstream"></div><p class="p-text">No wonder she’s throwing around the “B” word, predicting receivership and other financial calamity in a city that’s known its share under four state-appointed emergency managers. It’s the only leverage she has, short of a federal court order that forces council to act.</p><p class="p-text">But let’s be clear: as successful as Detroit’s Chapter 9 bankruptcy turned out to be — ahead of schedule, consensual deals with creditors, collective bargaining contracts with all of the city’s unions for the first time in recent memory — the chances of Gov. Rick Snyder approving bankruptcy for Flint are next to nil.</p><p class="p-text">In what effectively would be the last year of his term? In the city whose plight (thanks largely to state ineptitude) did more to tarnish Snyder’s reputation than all other things combined? In a town that is the state’s second-largest minority-majority city behind Detroit?</p><p class="p-text">The words “no way” are, in this case, insufficient. As much as Flint’s books and its contracts with vendors, unions and utilities like GLWA and KWA might benefit from the restructuring only municipal bankruptcy can deliver, its probably safe to say it won’t happen.</p><p class="p-text">And that’s probably a major reason Flint council members are dithering: because they can. Because the political benefits redound more to them than they do the mayor. Because wary residents are more likely to reward an overabundance of caution than a summary concession to Lansing’s preferred option.</p><p class="p-text">Except this: What other option does Flint actually have for its water supply? Investing even more in a renovation of its mostly moribund water treatment plant so the city can pump KWA water into its homes and businesses?</p><p class="p-text">After all the drama of the past few years, try selling that to residents traumatized by the switch to untreated Flint River water and the lead contamination it unleashed. But that’s the only practical alternative to rejoining GLWA and its legacy connection to the Detroit Water and Sewerage Department.</p><p class="p-text">Negotiate a shorter-term deal with GLWA, as some council members have suggested? Possible, but equally favorable terms — including monthly credits that equal Flint’s debt obligation to KWA — are less likely in an industry whose financials depend on long-term agreements.</p><p class="p-text">You know, just like cities and towns do, the better to map budgets, to plan capital spending and to set local water fees charged to residents and businesses.</p><p class="p-text">Flint’s mayor may not be able to actually deliver on the bankruptcy threat. But council’s indecision isn’t likely to deliver, either. Flint needs stable, predictable, quality water, and sticking with GLWA and Detroit remains its best option.</p><p class="p-text"><span class="-newsgate-paragraph-cci-endnote-contact-">Daniel.Howes@detroitnews.com</span></p><p class="p-text"><span class="-newsgate-paragraph-cci-endnote-contact-">(313) 222-2106</span></p><p class="p-text"><span class="-newsgate-paragraph-cci-endnote-contact-">Daniel Howes’ column runs Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays. Follow him on Twitter @DanielHowes_TDN, listen to his Saturday <a alt="http://www.detroitnews.com/staff/27151/daniel-howes/" href="http://www.detroitnews.com/staff/27151/daniel-howes/" title="http://www.detroitnews.com/staff/27151/daniel-howes/">podcasts</a>, or catch him 3 and 10 p.m. Thursdays on Michigan Radio’s “Stateside,” 91.7 FM.</span></p><div class="story-asset <script id="json-ld" type="application/ld+json">{
    "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
    "url": "http:\/\/www.wtae.com\/article\/dep-orders-pwsa-to-make-critical-infrastrucure-improvements\/13094532",
    "name": "DEP orders PWSA to make critical infrastrucure improvements",
    "headline": "DEP orders PWSA to make critical infrastrucure improvements",
    "articleBody": "The Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) issued an administrative order requiring the Pittsburgh Water and Sewer Authority to make critical improvements to its infrastructure and repairs to its public drinking water system.The order only pertains to infrastructure, no boil water advisory is in effect and no action is required by PWSA customers.The order requires PWSA to take action according to a schedule to ensure the system's ability to provide a continuous supply of safe water in terms of pressure and volume. It does not present an imminent threat from contaminants. The DEP listed the following actions for PWSA to take:Restore the Lanpher Reservoir to service by completing repairs to the cover of the east cell of the reservoir initially, and ultimately the replacement of the covers and liners of both the east and west cells;Resume operation of the Highland 1 Reservoir, which would require either the addition of an ultraviolet disinfection unit and other upgrades to the Highland Membrane Filtration Plant or the covering of the Highland 1 Reservoir, which would negate the need for operation of the Membrane Filtration Plant;Ensure reliability of the Bruecken Pump Station by installing a backup pump and emergency backup power supply; andTake necessary actions to assure that water at adequate pressure is continuously supplied to users.",
    "datePublished": "2017-10-25T22:18:35Z",
    "dateModified": "2017-10-25T22:18:37.374319Z",

<div class="article-content--body-teaser">

<div class="article-content--body-text">
<strong class="dateline">PITTSBURGH —</strong> <p>The Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) issued an administrative order requiring the Pittsburgh Water and Sewer Authority to make critical improvements to its infrastructure and repairs to its public drinking water system.</p><p>The order only pertains to infrastructure, no boil water advisory is in effect and no action is required by PWSA customers.</p><div class="article-content--body-wrapper-side-floater ">
<!-- blocks/ad.twig -->
<div class="ad-rectangle ">
<div class="ad-container or-halfpage" data-loc="btf" data-type="rectangle"></div>
<div class="ad-label">Advertisement</div>
</div>
<!-- blocks/ad.twig -->
</div>
<p>The order requires PWSA to take action according to a schedule to ensure the system's ability to provide a continuous supply of safe water in terms of pressure and volume. It does not present an imminent threat from contaminants. </p><p>The DEP listed the following actions for PWSA to take:</p><ul><li>Restore the Lanpher Reservoir to service by completing repairs to the cover of the east cell of the reservoir initially, and ultimately the replacement of the covers and liners of both the east and west cells;</li><li>Resume operation of the Highland 1 Reservoir, which would require either the addition of an ultraviolet disinfection unit and other upgrades to the Highland Membrane Filtration Plant or the covering of the Highland 1 Reservoir, which would negate the need for operation of the Membrane Filtration Plant;</li><li>Ensure reliability of the Bruecken Pump Station by installing a backup pump and emergency backup power supply; and</li><li>Take necessary actions to assure that water at adequate pressure is continuously supplied to users.</li></ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="article-content--footer">
</div>
</div>

Private water wells in Texas test positive for contamination after Harvey
1 / 79
Back to Gallery

In the wake of Hurricane Harvey, nearly 60 percent of water samples from 50 private wells in Harris County tested positive for a bacteria sometimes found in feces, according to preliminary data released Wednesday.

The presence of total coliform, a bacteria sometimes found in feces but more commonly in soil and floodwater, was detected along with the more troubling E. coli. In Harris County, 18 percent of the samples revealed E. coli.

Experts warn that residents should not use water from their flooded well for cooking, bathing or drinking until it is tested because it can contain sewage from flooded wastewater treatment plants as well as manure, among other things.

COMPLETE COVERAGE: From before landfall to flooding after, read all about Hurricane Harvey

The data, released by Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, was analyzed after researchers there joined with Texas A&M University's AgriLife Extension Service to distribute free water sampling kits to residents who have private wells in counties impacted by Harvey.

The universities distributed 1,200 kits to residents, and received back 630 samples from 21 counties. All told, 47 percent of the samples tested positive for total coliform.

Now Playing:

On the morning of Sunday, August 27, Houston Chronicle Managing Editor Vernon Loeb wrote in an email to the entire newsroom: "We are heading into a severe flooding emergency and everyone on the Chronicle editorial staff is activated." For the days and that followed most of the staff covered the effects of Hurricane Harvey and little else.

Media: Scott Kingsley, Houston Chronicle

Total coliform tests often are used to determine the cleanliness of drinking water from private wells, but the presence of the bacteria does not mean those who consume the water will inevitably get sick, according to the Neilson Research Corporation, an Oregon-based company that conducts laboratory services for environmental projects, such as well water.

Total coliform's presence "indicates that a contamination pathway exists between a source of bacteria (surface water, septic system, animal waste, etc.) and the water supply," according to the corporation's website. "Disease-causing bacteria may use this pathway to enter the water supply."

More than 10 percent of wells, however, tested positive for E. coli, which suggests the water is contaminated with human or animal waste and is a better marker for the potential to cause disease, according to a Virginia Tech website.

In both cases, residents should decontaminate their wells, the website stated.

Virginia Tech noted Wednesday that these samples contain a mix of flooded and non-flooded drinking water wells, as well as non-drinking wells, so the actual rate of contamination associated with flooding could be higher or lower than the preliminary numbers show. They will be surveying well owners to better separate out the flooded drinking water wells.

In the days and weeks following Harvey's landfall Aug. 25, about 148 million gallons of raw sewage and industrial discharges spilled from wastewater treatment plants in counties impacted by the storm, according to the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality as of last week. More than 100 companies, including Valero Energy, Exxon Mobil and Arkema, had reported chemical spills as of last month, according to U.S. Coast Guard data.

The effort to inform Texans about the safety of their private water wells began in the weeks following Harvey, when Virginia Tech researcher Kelsey Pieper reached out to Texas A&M to offer assistance.

Pieper had led a similar effort to test for contaminants in flooded Louisiana wells a few years prior, she said, and was well acquainted with how to conduct the tests efficiently.

So with a $200,000 federal grant in hand, Pieper and her team shipped 1,200 water sampling kits to Texas. Those kits were then made available for free throughout September to residents with private wells in counties impacted by the storm.

Most of the testing was done in Virginia, said Drew Gholson, AgriLife Service program specialist and Texas Well Owner Network coordinator.

All individuals whose water came back positive for contaminants already have been informed, he said, and given information about how to decontaminate them. More information about this process can be found at the Texas A&M's website.

Diane Boellstorff, an AgriLife Extension water resource specialist, said Wednesday that residents generally were grateful to receive the news, which allowed them to take steps to ensure their drinking water was safe.

The most submitted water samples — 177 — came from Wharton County, where 50 percent tested positive for total coliform and 18 percent tested positive for E. coli, the data showed.

In Victoria County, researchers found that 42 percent of the 105 well water samples tested contained total coliform and 5 percent contained E. coli.

And in Liberty County, 63 percent of the 48 well water samples contained total coliform and 13 percent contained E. coli.

In about a half-dozen counties, no E. coli was detected, according to the data.

Virginia Tech researchers currently are gathering information from residents who submitted samples about how they receive information during flood events, Pieper said.

"We're asking them to complete a survey to understand where they look for information during disasters so we can better equip people during future events," she said. "We're asking them what information they want and where they want it available."

Pieper will use this information to create a comprehensive guide on how to communicate with water well owners during future natural disasters.

In the coming weeks, Gholson said Texas A&M will take up the testing reins as another round of sampling kits are handed out. He expects Texas researchers to hand out about 2,000 kits, though they are still waiting on federal funding to cover costs.

Information about when and where to pick up these additional kits is not yet available.

Alex Stuckey covers science and the environment for the Houston Chronicle. You can reach her at alex.stuckey@chron.com or Twitter.com/alexdstuckey.

How long it could take to repair massive Oakland County water main break

9:03 AM, Oct 24, 2017
11:27 AM, Oct 24, 2017
Share Article

FARMINGTON HILLS, Mich. (WXYZ) - West Bloomfield police say it could take four to five days to repair a massive water main break in Farmington Hills that has 12 Oakland County communities on a boil water advisory.

  • Water main break puts 11 Oakland County cities under Boil Water Advisory
  • What to do during a Boil Water Advisory
  • Photo gallery: Crews work to repair massive water main break in Oakland Co.

"Due to the substantial extent of the current water main failure, repairing this problem and placing public water back into service and removing a Boil Water Advisory, it's estimated to take at least 4-5 days in duration in order to make necessary repairs and place the entire at-large water system of West Bloomfield into a no boil water status," police said in a Facebook post.

The Great Lakes Water Authority said a 48-inch diameter water main failed on Friday night. GLWA peronnel are on site to isolate the damaged portion of the main and work to drain the water from the roadway.

At the earliest, the GLWA says they have have a replacement pipe installed by Wednesday night, but they still have to complete two rounds of testing after the replacement.

That means the earliest they plan to lift the boil water advisory is late Friday night on Oct. 27.

The city of Novi is under a complete water shutoff and the city's emergency operations center has been activated.

They are one of 12 communities under the advisory, which also includes Bloomfield Township, Commerce Township, Farmington Hills, Keego Harbor, Novi Township, Oakland Township (specifically Kings Pointe & Hills of Oakland subs), Orchard Lake, Rochester Hills (north of Hamlin, west of Livernois), Walled Lake, West Bloomfield Township and Wixom.

Both Henry Ford Hospital in West Bloomfield and St. John Providence Park Hospital in Novi are closed.

Wixom, Walled Lake, Commerce Township and parts of Novi are located at the end of the main and can't be served water through another part of the GLWA system, meaning they could experience low to no water pressure.

Dozens of schools are closed because of the water main break.

Boil water advisory lifted for Wilson, remains in place for Clinton

2017-10-22T18:51:53Z2017-10-25T15:21:51Z
Posted by WAFB Staff
Email
Connect
newstips@wafb.com
Source: WAFB
LIVINGSTON, LA (WAFB) -

Boil advisories were issued for two communities in East Feliciana Parish after heavy flooding.

The advisory in Wilson has been lifted. According to officials, a water leak was found Sunday, which prompted the boil water advisory until the leak could be repaired.

Reports indicate a line may have burst, resulting in a boil water advisory being issued for Lower C C Road in the Clinton area. The boil order will remain in place until further notice.

BREAKING- Boil Water Order Lifted For Tupelo

0 Comments for this article
By: Robert Davidson
Submitted: 10/21/2017 - 1:16pm

TUPELO (WCBI)  –  The boil water notice for the City of Tupelo is over.  Follow up samples are back and the water is safe for consumption .

 

It is suggested that lines in the home be run for a time period in order to flush them .  Washing machines and dishwashers should also be put through a complete cycle just as a precaution .  The system  was placed under the notice Thursday  after a sample indicated total coliform and E-Coli were present.

Boil water order lifted in Astoria

Some neighborhoods were advised to boil water after a water line break Thursday

The Daily Astorian

Published on October 21, 2017 10:07AM


Astoria on Saturday lifted a boil water order for some neighborhoods off Highway 202.

The order had applied to Willowdale, Riverpoint, the county fairgrounds, the Oregon Department of Forestry office and Cavalier Court after a water line break Thursday.

“Bacteriological testing of the water has shown that the water is safe to drink,” Eric Bufkin, water quality supervisor for the Astoria Public Works Department, said in a statement.

The broken water line was repaired early Friday, the city said. Public Works staff conducted tests on several water samples to look for contaminants. The city said the test results showed no contamination.

<article class="content-single post-480653 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-health category-news" id="post-480653" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/Article">
<header class="entry-header">
<h1 class="entry-title" itemprop="headline">Boil and conserve water order issued for parts of Chautauqua County</h1>
<div class="entry-meta">
<div class="entry-meta-primary-column">
<img alt="" class="avatar avatar-44" height="44" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/9ab7f47e44995ded21a6f3dc65cfb78d?s=44&d=404&r=G" width="44"/>
<span class="byline">By <a class="author url fn" href="http://wivb.com/author/sara-mullen/" rel="author" title="Posts by Sara Mullen, News 4 Special Projects Manager">Sara Mullen, News 4 Special Projects Manager</a></span>
<span class="posted-on">
	Published: <time class="entry-date published" datetime="2017-10-21T13:13:44+00:00">October 21, 2017, 1:13 pm</time></span>
<span class="updated-on ">
	Updated: <time class="updated" data-standard-view="" datetime="2017-10-23T08:44:22+00:00">October 23, 2017, 8:44 am</time></span>
</div><!-- .entry-meta-primary-column -->

<div class="entry-content" id="entry-content">
<div class="entry-media-wrapper">
<figure class="entry-media ">
<img alt="" class="attachment-large size-large wp-post-image" data-attachment-id="480660" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-description="" data-image-meta='{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":"","orientation":"0"}' data-image-title="water" data-large-file="https://lintvwivb.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/water.jpg?w=650" data-medium-file="https://lintvwivb.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/water.jpg?w=300" data-orig-file="https://lintvwivb.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/water.jpg" data-orig-size="650,366" data-permalink="http://wivb.com/2017/10/21/boil-and-conserve-water-order-issued-for-parts-of-chautauqua-county/water-21/" height="366" sizes="(max-width: 650px) 100vw, 650px" src="https://lintvwivb.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/water.jpg?w=650" srcset="https://lintvwivb.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/water.jpg 650w, https://lintvwivb.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/water.jpg?w=150 150w, https://lintvwivb.files.wordpress.com/2017/10/water.jpg?w=300 300w" width="650"/>
</figure>
</div>
<div class="entry-content-wrap" itemprop="articleBody">
<p><strong>MAYVILLE, N.Y. (WIVB) –  </strong>The Chautauqua County Department of Health & Human Services has issued a mandatory order effective immediately to both boil and conserve water for all customers of the Village of Fredonia Public Water System in the Village of Fredonia and Town of Pomfret.</p>
<p>The Department of Health reports that a major leak was found in the Castel Heights area around 7:30 a.m. The leak was found after the water filter plant operator noted high water usage and decreasing water levels and capacity.</p>
<p>Officials have made repairs, but the order remains in effect until further notice. A second round of sampling needs to be satisfactorily completed.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong><u>BOIL WATER BEFORE USING</u></strong></p>
<p><span style="font-size:1.3rem;">Boiled or bottled water should be used for drinking, making ice, washing dishes, brushing teeth and preparing food and infant formula until further notice.</span></p>
<ul>
<li>Bring tap water to a rolling boil</li>
<li>boil for one minute</li>
<li>cool before using or use bottled water</li>
</ul>
<p>Contaminated water can make you sick. Harmful microbes may be present in the water and can cause diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, nausea, headaches or other symptoms and may pose a special health risk for infants, some elderly, and people with severely compromised immune systems. These symptoms are not just caused by microbes in drinking water. If you experience any of these symptoms and they persist, you should seek medical advice.</p>
<p><strong><u>CONSERVE WATER</u></strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Only use as much tap water as is essential.</li>
<li>No outside watering of lawns, shrubs, plants, etc.</li>
<li>No washing cars, trucks, trailers, decks, houses, sidewalks, driveways, etc</li>
<li>. Use paper plates and utensils to avoid dishwashing.</li>
<li>Limit showers and baths.</li>
<li>Do only full loads of laundry.</li>
</ul>
<p> </p>
<p> </p>

<div class="asset-content subscriber-premium" itemprop="articleBody">
<style>#ndn-video-player-1.ndn_embedded .ndn_floatContainer { margin-top: 10px; margin-bottom: 20px; }</style>
<div class="ndn-container p402_hide">
<div class="ndn_embed" data-config-distributor-id="92130" data-config-height="9/16w" data-config-width="100%" id="ndn-video-player-1"></div>
<script type="text/javascript">var _ndnq = _ndnq || []; _ndnq.push(['embed']);</script>
</div>
<style>#ndn-video-player-2.ndn_embedded .ndn_floatContainer { margin-top: 10px; margin-bottom: 20px; }</style>
<div class="ndn-container p402_hide">
<div class="ndn_embed" data-config-distributor-id="92130" data-config-height="9/16w" data-config-width="100%" id="ndn-video-player-2"></div>
<script type="text/javascript">var _ndnq = _ndnq || []; _ndnq.push(['embed']);</script>
</div>
<p>FULTON, Ill. — Due to a major water main break, residents living in the south end of Fulton are under a boil order.</p><p>Fulton officials announced shortly before 9:30 p.m. Friday that most areas south of 15th Avenue are affected, with residences between Illinois 84 and Fourth Street south of 15th Avenue under the order.</p>
<div data-tnt-ads-tmp='{"vendor":"blox","type":"region","region":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset","id":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset","pos":"fixed-big-ad-top-asset, atf","fold":"above","include_domain":"cnhi\/clintonherald","size":"[300,250]","height":"250","width":"300","mobile":false,"js":{"video":"https:\/\/bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com\/clintonherald.com\/shared-content\/art\/tncms\/templates\/libraries\/flex\/components\/video\/resources\/scripts\/video.512a6903eae08e033c76afdce2a0eac7.js"},"overline":null,"index_slug":null,"url":"\/news"}' style="display:none;"></div>
<div data-refreshable="true" data-region="fixed-big-ad-top-asset">
</div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_top"></div><p>Water is shut off at the present time and will be for several hours so that Public Works employees can repair the main.</p>
<p>Once the water is turned back on, the boil order will remain in effect for at least 24 hours. At this time, officials say residents are to boil drinking and cooking water for five minutes prior to use as a precautionary measure.</p>
<div data-tnt-ads-tmp='{"vendor":"blox","type":"region","region":"fixed-big-ad-middle-asset","id":"fixed-big-ad-middle-asset","pos":"fixed-big-ad-middle-asset, stf","fold":"span","include_domain":"cnhi\/clintonherald","size":"[300,250]","height":"250","width":"300","mobile":false,"js":{"video":"https:\/\/bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com\/clintonherald.com\/shared-content\/art\/tncms\/templates\/libraries\/flex\/components\/video\/resources\/scripts\/video.512a6903eae08e033c76afdce2a0eac7.js"},"overline":null,"index_slug":null,"url":"\/news"}' style="display:none;"></div>
<div data-refreshable="true" data-region="fixed-big-ad-middle-asset">
</div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_middle"><div class="tncms-block visible-xs" id="tncms-block-1150482">
<!-- Mobile Rectangle ATF 300x250 article -->
<div class="visible-xs visible-sm" id="mobileRectangle_atf" style="width:100%;text-align:center">
<script type="text/javascript">
AdBridg.cmd.push(function() { AdBridg.display('mobileRectangle_atf'); });
</script>
</div>
<div class="clear" style="padding-bottom:10px"></div>
</div></div><p>Residents are to call Fulton City Hall at (815) 589-2616 for more detailed instructions and to see when the boil order will be lifted.</p>
<div data-tnt-ads-tmp='{"vendor":"blox","type":"region","region":"fixed-big-ad-bottom-asset","id":"fixed-big-ad-bottom-asset","pos":"fixed-big-ad-bottom-asset, btf","fold":"below","include_domain":"cnhi\/clintonherald","size":"[300,250]","height":"250","width":"300","mobile":false,"js":{"video":"https:\/\/bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com\/clintonherald.com\/shared-content\/art\/tncms\/templates\/libraries\/flex\/components\/video\/resources\/scripts\/video.512a6903eae08e033c76afdce2a0eac7.js"},"overline":null,"index_slug":null,"url":"\/news"}' style="display:none;"></div>

<script>
    $(function(){
       var zipcodes = [];

       $.each($('.subscription-services .subscription-service.subscription-service-delivered'),function(){
           $(this).find('.service-sublink a.btn.btn-primary').on('click',function(){
               $('#zipcode-restriction').find('input[name=serviceid]').val($(this).attr('data-subscription-service'));
               zipcodes = $(this).attr('data-subscription-service-zipcodes').split(',');

               $('#template-metering').find('.metering-modal').modal('toggle');
               $('#zipcode-restriction').find('.modal').modal({});

               return false;
           });
       });


       $('#zipcode-restriction').find('.zipcode-restriction-modal').on('click',function(){
           $('#template-metering').find('.metering-modal').modal('toggle');
           $('#zipcode-restriction').find('.modal').modal({
               static:'static',
               keyboard:false
            });

            return false;
       });


       $('#zipcode-restriction').on('submit',function(){
           if($('#zipcode-restriction').find('[name=zipcode]').val()!=""){

               if($.inArray($('#zipcode-restriction').find('[name=zipcode]').val(), zipcodes) > -1){
                   console.log("form is valid, should submit");
               }else{
                   console.log("form is catching on zipcode check");

                   $('#zipcode-restriction').find('.zipcode-restriction-warning').removeClass('hidden').show();

                   return false;
               }
           } else {
               console.log("form is catching on zipcode blank check");
               return false;
           }
       });
    });
</script>
<script type="text/javascript">
    $(function(){
        var i = 0;
        $('#subscription-modal').find('.subscription-services').find('.subscription-service').each(function(){
            $(this).attr('id','service-tab-'+i);
        
            $(this).find('.panel-heading h3').html('<a href="" data-toggle="collapse" data-parent="services-modal-collapsable-tabs" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="service-tab-'+i+'">'+$(this).find('.panel-heading h3').text()+'</a>')
            $(this).find('.panel-body').addClass('panel-collapse collapse').attr('role','tabpanel');
            
            if(i==0){
                $(this).find('.panel-collapse').collapse('show');
                $(this).find('.panel-footer').show();
            }else{
                $(this).find('.panel-footer').hide();
            }
        
            i++;
        });
    
        $('.subscription-services-filter').hide();
        $('#subscription-modal').find('.subscription-services .subscription-service .service-heading').css({'padding':'0px'});
        $('#subscription-modal').find('.subscription-services .subscription-service .service-heading').find('a').css({'display':'block','padding':'10px 15px'});
        $('#subscription-modal').find('.subscription-services .subscription-service .service-heading').find('a[data-toggle=collapse]').on('click',function(event){
            var id = $(this).attr('aria-controls');
            var open = $('#'+id).find('.collapse').hasClass('in');
            
            $('#subscription-modal').find('.subscription-services .subscription-service').each(function(){
                if(this.id == id){
                    $(this).find('.panel-collapse').collapse('show');
                    $(this).find('.panel-footer').show();
                }else{
                    $(this).find('.panel-collapse').collapse('hide');
                    $(this).find('.panel-footer').hide();
                }
            });
        });
        
        $('#asset-content').find('.subscription-required').find('.panel-footer').find('a[data-toggle=collapse]').on('click',function(event){
            $(this).parents('.panel-footer').find('.collapse.collapse-rates').collapse('toggle');
        });
        
        
        $('#asset-content').find('.meter-modal-open').on('click',function(){
            $('#asset-content').find('.alert.notification').css({'z-index':'900'});
            $("#template-metering").find('.metering-modal').first().modal();
        
        });
        
        $('#eedition-subscription').find('.meter-modal-open').on('click',function(){
            $("#template-metering").find('.metering-modal').first().modal();
        });
    });
    
</script>

<div class="asset-content p402_premium subscriber-premium" itemprop="articleBody">
<div class="subscriber-preview"><p>TUPELO – Despite a citywide boil-water order, it was business as usual at most restaurants, stores and other businesses Friday.</p></div><div class="subscriber-preview"><p>Restaurant owners are taking every precaution they can to ensure the health and safety of not only their customers, but employees after a notice issued Thursday by the Mississippi Department of Health that a test revealed contaminated water in the Tupelo Water & Light supply.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>“We’ve got bottled water we’re shipping in, we’re buying all the Milo’s tea we can in town, and we’re making sure the dishwashing machines are up to standard, and they are,” said Bernard Bean, chief operating officer of the Eat With Us restaurant group which owns Sweet Peppers Deli, Harveys and Fairpark Grill.</p></div>
<!--nothing here-->
<div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_top"></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>“We’re not brewing our own tea or serving fountain drinks, and we’re serving bottled and canned drinks instead.”</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Bean said the dishwashers use sanitizers that kill bacteria, including the E. coli that was found in a water sample in the city’s water supply.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>“The chemicals kill everything,” he said.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>“We’re doing what every other restaurant is doing in some way,” he added.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Coffee shops also use water for everything from espresso and coffee makers to doing dishes and washing produce.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>While it was not unusually busy at Strange Brew Coffeehouse on Friday, one day after the boil water notice was issued, employees were being significantly more careful regarding food and drink preparation than the day before.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>The boiling point for water is 212 degrees Fahrenheit, and luckily for many coffee businesses in town, their espresso and coffee makers reach that temperature, Strange Brew owner Katelyn Reed said.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Reed said most of Strange Brew’s coffee machines and soda fountains have commercial-brand water filters, and the shop uses boiled water for general sanitation.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>“We’re taking this seriously, following the recommendations from the Health Department. But we are open for business and look forward to seeing all of our customers today,” she said.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Aptly named Cafe 212 also took additional precautions. The shop purchased purified water jugs to use in place of regular water and chose to sell only store-bought sweetened and unsweetened tea and bottled water, in addition to their coffee, which also reaches boiling point when prepared.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>“Our Coke machine is through the tap and when we brew our tea, it’s through the tap. Our espresso machine is fine, but for our coffee, we have big, purified water gallons that we use,” Cafe 212 employee Jordan West said.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>The shop washed its produce with water from an external source, but had to throw away many food items.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>“This morning we had to come in and redo our produce that we usually wash the night before,” West said.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Starbucks closed its two locations due to the boil water notice.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Local grocery stores Todd’s Big Star and Palmer’s Shoppers Value Foods saw a wave of customers hit the stores for water bottles and gallon jugs.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Todd’s Big Star was packed Friday afternoon, with customers pulling packs of bottled water from pallet displays as fast as employees could restock them.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Manager Joey Cole said the store has seen a marked increase in customers since Thursday evening.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>At 24 bottles of water to a case and 50 cases to a pallet, the company has sold over 14,000 bottles of water since Thursday evening.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>“Since 6 p.m. last night, we’ve sold 10 pallets of water, and we’ve gone to pick some more up. They’re loading it up at the warehouse now ... we’ve probably sold 600 cases of water since last night.”</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Todd’s is boiling water for sanitation purposes in its deli and meat department.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>“They’ve all got cases of water sitting next to the sinks to wash their hands and equipment with. They can’t use any other water,” Cole said.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Sherry Gravatt was shopping for water at Todd’s early Friday morning for her mother and sister.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>“I washed my face with wipes today, and I took a shower from the neck down and I’m using bottled water,” she said.</p></div>
<!--nothing here-->
<div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_middle"></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Gravatt has lived in Tupelo for 24 years, and cares for two individuals who require a sanitary environment. She boiled additional water for the entire week to care for an infant and her husband, who has pancreatic cancer.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>“I wanted to be able to wash all the dishes and bottles and everything with boiled water,” she said.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Damon Palmer of Palmer’s said his store gets three trucks of water per week and is expecting more on Sunday, but the store’s drink section is devoid of water.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>“I keep a whole trailer full of 19 pallets of water back there, but we had to get into it yesterday,” he said.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Palmer’s is using bottled water for cleaning produce.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Southern Fish & Steak owner Blake Estes said, “We will continue business as normal today. We have canned drinks, bottled water, bagged ice and tea made with distilled water. We have all of the correct sanitizers in place, also. We treat everyone’s health as if were our own.”</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>At Chick-Fil-A at Thompson Square, some customers were disappointed to learn biscuits weren’t available, along with several other items that require large volumes of water to be used.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>“We will not be serving a lot of items today,” franchise owner Jamey Finley said. “It was a struggle to find enough bottled water and drinks, and cleaning is requiring much more time.”</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>Lucas Foley, Chick-Fil-A’s quality control director, said the restaurant had to dispose of all produce that was prepped for sale today. Restaurant employees spent three hours Thursday night washing dishes, work that usually takes 45 minutes.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>“We are striving to provide the cleanest, healthiest option available at all times, but especially during this advisory,” Foley said.”We cannot put a cost on safety, and hope that our guests understand our limited menu during this time as we seek to keep them safe and happy.”</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>The Toyota Mississippi plant in Blue Springs relies on water from Tupelo, but its operations have not been affected, a spokeswoman said.</p></div><div class="subscriber-only"><p>However, Raybern Foods in Shannon – which produces millions of frozen and refrigerated deli sandwiches sold in Walmart, Sams and other retailers across the country – is not operating today due to the water situation.</p></div>
<!--nothing here-->
<div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_bottom"></div>
</div>

<script>
            $(window).load(function() {

                var bizTracked = [];
                var isUserAction = false;

                function trackActive(owl){
                    if( bizTracked.length == 7 ){
                        return;
                    }else{
                        var activeThings = $(owl).find('.owl-item.active');

                        $.each(activeThings, function(index, value){
                            var bizId = $(this).find('.card').data('bizid');
                            var hasBeenLogged = false;

                            bizTracked.forEach(function (item, index, array) {
                                if(item == bizId){
                                    hasBeenLogged = true;
                                    return true;
                                }
                            });
                            if( hasBeenLogged == false ){
                                bizTracked.push(bizId);
                                TNCMS.Tracking.addEvent({
                                    app: 'business',
                                    metric: 'block',
                                    id: bizId
                                });
                            }
                        });
                    }
                }

                window.card_carousel_525711 = $('#block-525711 .owl-carousel');

                

                card_carousel_525711.owlCarousel({
                    loop:true,
                    margin:15,
                    nav:false,
                    dots:false,
                    slideBy: 'page',
                    autoHeight:false,
                    
                        autoplay: true,
                        autoplayHoverPause: true, 
                        autoplayTimeout: 5000,

        jQuery(document).ready(function($){
            var bThrottle = false;
            var $region = $('#tncms-region-asset_side_sticky');

            if (
                $region.is(':empty') === false &&
                $('.main-sidebar').height() + $(window).height() < $('.main-content').height() &&
                window.innerWidth >= 992
            ) {
                var $tempRegion = $('<div id="asset_side_sticky-placeholder"></div>');
                $region.before($tempRegion);
                $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );

                $(window).on('scroll mousewheel', function(){
                    if( bThrottle === false ){
                        bThrottle = true;

                        setTimeout(function(){
                            var iFixPoint = $region.offset().top - 80;
                            var iCurPoint = $(this).scrollTop();

                            if (iCurPoint < $tempRegion.offset().top - 80) {
                                $region.css('top', null);
                                $region.removeClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else if (
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#infinite-container') ||
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#site-footer-container')
                            ) {
                                $region.removeClass('affix')
                                $region.addClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else {
                                $region.css('top', 80);
                                $region.addClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');
                            }
                            bThrottle = false;
                        }, 25);
                    }
                });

                $(window).on('resize', function(){
                    $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );
                });
            }
        });

Boil water advisory rescinded for Assaria, Saline Co.

October 20, 2017 by Post Staff Leave a Comment

The Kansas Department of Health and Environment (KDHE) has rescinded a boil water advisory for the City of Assaria in Saline County. KDHE officials issued the advisory because the systems need to repair a fire hydrant. The repairs will cause a loss of pressure. Failure to maintain adequate pressure may result in a loss of chlorine residuals and bacterial contamination.

Public water suppliers in Kansas take all measures necessary to notify customers quickly after a system failure or shutdown. Regardless of whether it’s the supplier or KDHE that announces a boil water advisory, KDHE will issue the rescind order following testing at a certified laboratory.

Laboratory testing samples collected from the City of Assaria indicate no evidence of contamination and all other conditions that placed the system at risk of contamination are deemed by KDHE officials to be resolved.

Wastewater spill along Buffalo Bayou forces some residents to boil water
1 / 50
Back to Gallery

Houston city officials have issued a boil order for residents who get water from private drinking wells because of a Hurricane Harvey-related embankment collapse on the south bank of Buffalo Bayou.

As a result of the collaspe, a 42-inch sanitary sewer pipe began spilling thousands of gallons of wastewater. More than 300,000 gallons was released by 11 a.m., according to the city.

The area affected by the spill spans from 9602 Longmont to at least 300 feet downstream of Buffalo Bayou. 

Residents using private drinking water supply wells located within a half a mile of the spill site are urged to either boil or use distilled water for drinking, cooking, bathing and brushing their teeth.

Now Playing:

Task Force 4 of the East Bay and other rescue crews were sent to help Harvey survivors. There are early estimates that at least 30,000 homes have been damaged. Ken Wayne reports from the Buffalo Bayou

Media: JW Player

The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality and local government officials have been notified, the news release from the city stated.  

Houston Public Works is also closely monitoring the situation and installing a by-pass pump to  provide wastewater service to customers until permanent repairs can be made. 

Access to the area is  difficult and the ground remains unstable due to storm damage, which makes completing repairs complex, according to the news release. 

Individuals with private water wells should have their well water tested and disinfected if necessary. 

If members of the public come into contact with waste material, soil or water affected by the spill, they should bathe and wash clothes as thoroughly as possible.

Boil water advisory issued for Assaria, Saline Co.

October 18, 2017 by News Release Leave a Comment

TOPEKA, Kan. – The Kansas Department of Health and Environment (KDHE) has issued a boil water advisory for the public water supply located in the City of Assaria in Saline County.  KDHE officials issued the advisory because the systems needs to repair a fire hydrant.  The repairs will cause a loss of pressure. Failure to maintain adequate pressure may result in a loss of chlorine residuals and bacterial contamination.

The advisory took effect on October 18, 2017and will remain in effect until conditions which place the system at risk of contamination are deemed by KDHE officials to be adequately resolved.

Customers should observe the following precautions until further notice:

  • Boil water for one minute prior to drinking or food preparation, or use bottled water.
  • Dispose of ice cubes and do not use ice from a household automatic icemaker.
  • Disinfect dishes and other food contact surfaces by immersion for at least one minute in clean tap water that contains one teaspoon of unscented household bleach per gallon of water.
  • Water used for bathing does not generally need to be boiled. Supervision of children is necessary while bathing so that water is not ingested. Persons with cuts or severe rashes may wish to consult their physicians.
  • If your tap water appears dirty, flush the water lines by letting the water run until it clears.

Public water suppliers in Kansas take all measures necessary to notify customers quickly after a system failure. Regardless of whether it’s the supplier or KDHE that announces a boil water advisory, KDHE will issue the rescind order following testing at a certified laboratory.

<div class="asset-content p402_premium subscriber-premium" itemprop="articleBody">
<div class="subscriber-preview"><p>PINCKNEYVILLE — Water service will be shut off for Pinckneyville water customers from 9 a.m. until repair of a water main leak is completed Thursday, Oct. 19. When water service is restored a boil water order will be in effect for water customers on New Street, Bathon Drive, Cripple Creek and Unicorn roads, Red Bud Lane, Cedar Point and all customers along Illinois 127 south of the viaduct. </p></div><div class="tnt-ads-container text-center hidden-sm hidden-md hidden-lg"><div class="tnt-ads dfp-ad" data-dfp-adunit="/8438/thesouthern.com/news/local" data-dfp-custom-pos="fixed-big-ad-top, atf" data-dfp-size="[300,250]" id="fixed-big-ad-top-mobile" style="min-height:250px; min-width:300px;"></div></div>
<div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_top"></div><div class="subscriber-preview"><p>The boil water order will remain in effect until further notice.</p></div><div class="tnt-ads-container text-center hidden-sm hidden-md hidden-lg"><div class="tnt-ads dfp-ad" data-dfp-adunit="/8438/thesouthern.com/news/local" data-dfp-custom-pos="fixed-big-ad-middle, stf" data-dfp-size="[300,250]" id="fixed-big-ad-middle-mobile" style="min-height:250px; min-width:300px;"></div></div>
<div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_middle"></div><div class="tnt-ads-container text-center "><div class="tnt-ads dfp-ad" data-dfp-adunit="/8438/thesouthern.com/news/local" data-dfp-custom-pos="fixed-inline-video, stf" data-dfp-size="[4,1]" data-lazy="true" id="fixed-inline-video" style="min-height:1px; min-width:4px;"></div></div>
<div class="subscriber-only"><p>Please continue to monitor this media for any further notices or the city’s website, <a href="http://www.ci.pinckneyville.il.us">www.ci.pinckneyville.il.us</a>.</p></div><div class="tncms-region hidden-print" id="tncms-region-article_instory_bottom"></div>
</div>

        jQuery(document).ready(function($){
            var bThrottle = false;
            var $region = $('#tncms-region-asset_side_sticky');

            if (
                $region.is(':empty') === false &&
                $('.main-sidebar').height() + $(window).height() < $('.main-content').height() &&
                window.innerWidth >= 992
            ) {
                var $tempRegion = $('<div id="asset_side_sticky-placeholder"></div>');
                $region.before($tempRegion);
                $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );

                $(window).on('scroll mousewheel', function(){
                    if( bThrottle === false ){
                        bThrottle = true;

                        setTimeout(function(){
                            var iFixPoint = $region.offset().top - 80;
                            var iCurPoint = $(this).scrollTop();

                            if (iCurPoint < $tempRegion.offset().top - 80) {
                                $region.css('top', null);
                                $region.removeClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else if (
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#infinite-container') ||
                                __tnt.elementOnScreen('#site-footer-container')
                            ) {
                                $region.removeClass('affix')
                                $region.addClass('affix-bottom');

                            } else {
                                $region.css('top', 80);
                                $region.addClass('affix');
                                $region.removeClass('affix-bottom');
                            }
                            bThrottle = false;
                        }, 25);
                    }
                });

                $(window).on('resize', function(){
                    $region.width( $tempRegion.width() );
                });
            }
        });
    </script>
